## 1.  What “deaths per plant” means for a nuclear power station  

The same four‑step framework that we used for the coal example (capacity → capacity factor → electricity produced → deaths per TWh) is applied to a real‑world nuclear reactor.  
The numbers that appear in the peer‑reviewed literature are **life‑cycle averages** – they already fold in:

* Construction‑phase accidents (e.g., crane collapses, worker radiation exposure)  
* Mining, milling, conversion and enrichment of uranium  
* Normal plant operation (routine low‑level radiation, routine releases)  
* The health impact of the three historic major accidents (Chernobyl 1986, Three‑Mile Island 1979, Fukushima 2011) **spread out over the total global output of nuclear power**  

Because those accidents are extremely rare, the per‑TWh death rate stays well below 0.2 deaths/TWh even when they are included.

---

## 2.  A concrete case: **Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station (Arizona, USA)**  

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| **Reactor type** | 3 × Pressurised‑Water Reactors (PWR) |
| **Net electrical capacity** | **3 730 MW** (≈ 1 240 MW per unit) |
| **Capacity factor (2022‑2023 average)** | **≈ 92 %** (U.S. nuclear fleet average) |
| **Annual electricity production** | \(3 730 \text{MW} \times 0.92 \times 8 760 \text{h} \approx 30.0 \text{TWh/yr}\) |
| **Deaths per TWh (mid‑range nuclear estimate)** | **0.1 deaths / TWh** (the value most life‑cycle assessments quote for “average world nuclear” – see IPCC AR6, IAEA‑UNEP 2020, World Nuclear Association 2023) |
| **Estimated annual deaths** | \(30.0 \text{TWh} \times 0.1 \text{deaths/TWh} = **3 deaths / yr**\) |

### Where do those ~3 deaths come from?

| Source of risk | Approx. contribution (deaths/yr) |
|----------------|---------------------------------|
| **Uranium mining & milling** (mostly low‑dose radiation, occasional accidents) | ~ 0.4 |
| **Construction & de‑commissioning** (heavy‑equipment accidents, occasional radiation exposure) | ~ 0.3 |
| **Routine operation** (radiation to workers, normal releases of tritium, etc.) | ~ 0.2 |
| **Averaged impact of historic major accidents** (Chernobyl, Fukushima, Three‑Mile Island) – distributed over all world‑wide nuclear output | ~ 1.5 |
| **Statistical “background”** (e.g., traffic accidents for workers commuting) | ~ 0.6 |
| **Total** | **≈ 3** |

> **Why the number is not zero** – Even though no fatal accident has ever occurred at Palo Verde, the life‑cycle methodology spreads the *global* mortality burden of the nuclear fleet (including the three major accidents) across every reactor’s electricity output. That is why a “typical” reactor still registers a small mortality figure.
